clinical_study.brief_title: Psychological Impact of Admission With Covid-19 During the SARS-CoV-2 Pandemic: Clinical Trial of a Digital Intervention to Improve Wellbeing
clinical_study.official_title: Psychological Impact of Admission With Covid-19 During the SARS-CoV-2 Pandemic: Clinical Trial of a Digital Intervention to Improve Wellbeing

lead_sponsor.agency: Royal Free Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: Royal Free Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: This is a randomised control trial to look at the impact of a digital tool, which uses relaxation and mindfullness based cognitive therapy, for twelve days on those who have prolonged mental distress from being admitted with Covid-19 during the peak of the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic.

detailed_description.textblock:
There are no studies that have looked at the psychological impact of being admitted with COVID-19 during the pandemic. It is important that the long-term wellbeing of patients who have been admitted is addressed. A newly published meta-analysis (Rogers et al 2020) has looked at both the psychiatric and neuropsychiatric consequences from the SARS and MERS outbreaks, showing increased risks of anxiety, depression and PTSD in both acutely and longer term. Excluding usual psychiatric services and some specialist ITU step down services, no interventions across the country have been set up to address the long-term psychological impacts of COVID-19.
This is a randomised control study looking at a digital psychological tool versus current treatment practises. It is not a blinded study. The null hypothesis is that patients admitted with COVID-19 who are given a digital psychological tool do not experience any benefit to their mental well-being.
Patients who were discharged during the peak of the pandemic, April 2020, will be contacted 2 months post discharged and a screening survey will assess their level of psychological distress. Those suffering symptoms of anxiety or PTSD will be invited to participate in the trial which involves 12 days of an intervention with short and long term follow up using validated anxiety, depression and PTSD scales.

primary_outcome.measure: Anxiety as measured by generalised anxiety disorder score (GAD-7) scale
primary_outcome.description: Generalised anxiety disorder score (GAD-7) scale. Score 0-21, with a higher score associated with greater anxiety symptoms. Scores of 5, 10, and 15 represent cut-points for mild, moderate, and severe anxiety, respectively. GAD-7 score at baseline will be controlled for.

secondary_outcome.measure: Depression as measured by the patient health questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9)
secondary_outcome.description: The Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) is a screening tool for the identification of depressive disorders, which has been validated for use in primary care. Each of the nine items in the questionnaire is based on the DSM diagnostic criteria for clinical depression. The PHQ-9 is scored out of 27 according to severity, where score of 5-9 indicates mild depression, 10-14 moderate, 15-19 moderately severe, and 20 or above severe depression.

secondary_outcome.measure: Trauma as measured by Trauma screening questionnaire (TSQ)
secondary_outcome.description: The Trauma screening questionnaire (TSQ) is a 10 point scale used to identify symptoms of post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), with a score between 0 and 10, with a score of 6 or higher scored as positive.

secondary_outcome.measure: Anxiety as measured by generalised anxiety disorder score (GAD-7) scale
secondary_outcome.description: Generalised anxiety disorder score (GAD-7) scale. Score 0-21, with a higher score associated with greater anxiety symptoms. Scores of 5, 10, and 15 represent cut-points for mild, moderate, and severe anxiety, respectively. GAD-7 score at baseline will be controlled for.

other_outcome.description: Risk factors for psychological distress from admission with Covid-19 will be collected, these will include, age, gender, ethnicity, length of hospital stay, oxygen requirement, co-morbidites, years of education, smoking status, occupation.

Framework analysis. Qualitative feedback of patient experience. Semi structured interviews of a subset of patients will be performed to gain further insight into the patient experience. These will be analysed using a framework thematic analysis, to identify themes which will then be used to code the text.

arm_group.description: Audio track to listen to everyday at least once for 12 days
Waiting list control arm To receive the digital intervention at 8 weeks, after the follow up questionnaire.

intervention.description: Audio based tracks using Jacobson relaxation and mindfullness based cognitive therapy (MBCT) techniques including positive visualisation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria
- Able to commit to listening to tracks for 12 days
- Between the ages 18-70
- Treated for Covid-19 at the Royal Free Hospital
- Discharged from the Royal Free Hospital in April 2020
- Capacity to consent AND
- At screening had a PHQ-2 score >=3 (positive) OR
- At screening had a TSQ score >= 6 (positive)
Exclusion criteria
- A current inpatient
- Participant on alternative trial that excludes being in a secondary trial
- Patient currently using alternative MBCT app tool
- Patients under 18 years old
- Patients over the age of 70
- Background of psychotic illness
- Patient declined
- Patient unable to consent
- Underlying cognitive impairment which may impede ability to comply with the intervention
- Severe hearing impairment
- Current delirium
- Was an in-patient in intensive care during hospital stay
- Unable to contact patient via telephone on 2 attempts
